title: Vastayan Language
body:
Dear any kind Rioters, 

I would like to write a fanfic related to Vastaya Champions, is it possible if a rioter around here can provide me with the structure of how Vastayah Language is created? As a fanfic writer, I would like to know more about Vastayah Language!

Kind regards.

replies.body:
Hey Ez, like Beyond Legends has already pointed out, there are actually many vastayan languages (since there are many vastayan tribes), so there's a lot of room for you to apply your own creativity! 

I actually helped create the language that Xayah quotes in-game, it's one of the coolest things I've gotten to do here at Riot! I don't think it's Lhotlan though. In fact, I know it's not because it was created for another tribe. {{sticker:slayer-jinx-wink}}  Xayah just knows how to speak it, from her travels.

It's actually not that easy to explain how the language works. It's a six page document, and that only covers a small  slice of the language; enough for me to write a handful of lines. 

Here are some of the things I thought about when creating the language, though (it's baraashi, for the record):

**How are sentences structured?** In English it's subject -> verb -> object, ex: I, love, cheese ravioli
Baraashi is subject -> object -> verb, ex: I, cheese ravioli, love

**How are verbs themselves handled?** Conjugation is where a lot of languages get complicated. So for simplicity, I avoided it for the most part (like in Chinese). Words before the verb indicate to who and when the verbs apply. However, there are examples where this changes, a second way to construct sentences that is still correct. ;) Languages are never simple...

**How long are words?** Compare German to Chinese. Baraashi words should be short, three syllables max.

**What sounds should be prevalent?** I looked at animals and Finnish as a starting point.

**And most importantly for all of the above... why?** CertainlyT actually _insisted_ that I sit down and make a bullet point list of what the people speaking the language are like, before anything else.

Anyway, without further ado, **here are some sample sentences, translated**.

I will gather magic. -> Baasi om soura.
Baasi (I, future)
Om (magic)
Soura (to gather)

They are not-vastaya. -> Faash vastaya na.
Faash (They, present)
Vastaya (vastaya)
Na (To not be)

Vi-om tann va’h.
Vi-om (wild-magic)
tann (here)
va'h (to be, present)

If you didn't recognize it, that last one is [a direct Xayah quote](https://vignette.wikia.nocookie.net/leagueoflegends/images/4/4c/Xayah.move18.ogg/revision/latest?cb=20170422022633). She doesn't pronounce it correctly btw, she has a "human" accent. Which I think says something interesting about the state of vastaya, struggling to stay in touch with their heritage.


tldr, creating languages is actually fun! I apologize for all the times I judged Tolkien for writing elvish poems.

Thank you for your reply! Lastly, may I ask which language should I refer to if I want to learn more of their words?
Like Soura( to gather)

To use other verbs to make other kind of sentence like:
Baasi om ( use ).

I referred to Finnish and Arabic (just for inspiration) and threw in some personal easter eggs as well. Like, the name of a friend's sister became the word for small. :D If you create enough of the words, at a certain point they'll just "sound right." Best of luck!
Just for the Vastayan language that Xayah or Rakan know of.

Would you ever be interested in expanding the language into a "learnable" conlang similar to LoTR with Sindarin/Quenya? As a polyglot (English, Korean, Danish, Russian, Mandarin and French and Sindarin, Valyrian and a little Dothraki and my own language Selisara) and linguistics enthusiast I personally would love to be able to speak the same language as my favourite champion in League.

Or if that's a no, do I have your blessing to further develop the language?

As we say in Selisara "Heni saran far taalasi" which means Many thanks I give to you.
Yes please, As a Main Rakan I would love to learn his language, could be possible to you share your developed vastayan language with me sometime? {{sticker:sg-kiko}}

> If you didn't recognize it, that last one is a direct Xayah quote. She doesn't pronounce it correctly btw, she has a "human" accent

I think it says something about her voice actress alright :p
Ah, she did great. I'm just building some head canon.
Man. Hearing Rioters have fun with their creativity is the most heart warming thing I've read on this board.

Hi Interlocutioner,
I'm sorry I might be late to the conversation, but I think I could use your help, and this very comment is the nearest thing I've found in the internet that could help me. I'm a young linguist with a passion for invented languages, and I'm doing researches on my own for a little project. I haven't had any luck when looking for information about fully developed conlangs created by Riot Games for the Runeterra universe, can you provide me with some information about the linguistic aspects of Runeterra? Is there an article, page, document I can download, essay I can read, book I can buy, on the matter? I would like to have every information existing at the moment on the languages spoken in Runeterra, with the full grammars of those languages, if available. Thanks in advance for your help!

Hey Treni, sadly there's nothing official that I can provide for League. Even the stuff above, it's just my opinion/fun backstory, until we publish a vastaya dictionary. {{sticker:slayer-jinx-wink}}  

I want to help if I can though, so here are some random links for fantasy languages I've personally found interesting over the years.

[Kingkiller Chronicles](http://kingkiller.wikia.com/wiki/Languages_in_Temerant) - languages are used to tease a lot of lore details in this series, character names really matter
[Clockwork Orange](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nadsat) - invented words that are somehow more fitting and descriptive than English
[Enochian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enochian) - invented angel language used by 17th century spirit mediums, the alphabet is even cooler

Anyway, you probably know a lot more about this than I do (I had to look up conlang). When you finish your project I'd love to check it out, if you don't mind sharing!
